line_1: Twa Dogs, that were na thrang at hame;
THE wars are all o'er and my Harry's at hame,
line_2: What else can I want now I've got him again!

line_1: Then the neighbours come in and they welcome him hame,
line_2: And I fa' a greeting, though much I think shame;

line_1: To do some errands, and convoy her hame.
line_2: Jenny, wha kens the meaning o' the same,

line_1: To do some errands, and convoy her hame.
line_2: The wily Mother sees the conscious flame

line_1: To do some errands, and convoy her hame.
line_2: With heart-struck, anxious care enquires his name,

line_1: An' tho' yon lowan heugh's thy hame,
line_2: Great is thy pow'r, an' great thy fame;

line_1: An' tho' yon lowan heugh's thy hame,
line_2: Far kend an' noted is thy name;

line_1: An' tho' yon lowan heugh's thy hame,
line_2: An' faith! thou's neither lag nor lame,

line_1: I'LL hae a new coatie when Willie comes hame,
line_2: I'll hae a new plaidie an' a' o' the same;

line_1: For I'll ay be canty when Willie comes hame,
line_2: To like sic a laddie why should I think shame!

line_1: For I maun be happy when Willie comes hame,
line_2: To lo'e the dear laddie I'll never think shame!

line_1: Sae I'll ay be canty when Willie comes hame,
line_2: To lo'e sic a laddie why should I think shame!

line_1: To stay content wi' yowes at hame;
line_2: An' warn him ay at ridin time,

line_1: That's better than to sit at hame
line_2: An ape I think's a harmless thing
